Updating from 66/34/0. OK I did minimal research and apparently the median time from nomination to confirmation since 1975 is 71 days. ACB was nominated 26 Sep 2020, so that gives 97 days until 1 Jan 2021. So the outside view is it is quite likely she would be confirmed in the timeframe. The inside view is that this is an election year and Reps are very motivated to get another Justice in, in case they are voted out. There is a lot of talk about hypocrisy relating to events in 2016 but ultimately there are no laws against hypocrisy, and no mechanism for Dems to enforce any punishments. As far as I can tell, Dems are quite powerless about this. Which means Reps will probably get their way. On top of this, the Rep majority is substantial: 53 plus the VP. So it is pointless for up to 3 Reps to defect, even if they thought it was "the right thing to do". They wouldn't change anything, and would fall out with their own party. You'd need at least 4, and are there 4 Senators who are not purely partisan, in either party? I don't follow politics that closely but it feels like the two parties are currently in the bad equilibrium of the iterated prisoners' dilemma and have been for at least 10 years. And even here, the only defections I have read about concern confirming before vs after the election. If I try to think of a reason why Reps would not confirm, I can only come up with something I read a while ago, that Trump himself would not want to confirm before the election, in order to motivate Rep voters to turn out. That was never super convincing, as it would motivate Dem voters equally. And it's looking even more flimsy now. In any case it does not rule out confirming after the election. All the above suggests 90% chance of confirmation, but then again I did little research and I don't know much about this so let's knock it down to 80%.

September 26, President Trump announced his nomination of appellate judge Amy Coney Barrett. Major media outlets report a majority of senators will vote to confirm Trump's nominee.

According to the Senate website (https://www.senate.gov/legislative/nominations/SupremeCourtNominations1789present.htm), whenever a nomination is made, 73% of the nominees are confirmed and serve.  In the last 50 years, 85% (11/13 - and the other two were withdrawn by the president) of nominees are confirmed when the same party controls the WH and the Senate.  Thus, the question turns to timing in my mind. Base rate is not easy for this one. Do you include all Supreme Court nominations since 1789? 1945? 1987?  When I started this analysis, I thought the Bork nomination in 1987 was a stark dividing line representing a fundamental change in the Supreme Court nomination process. The numbers don't support this conclusion. More important is if the same party controls both the White House and the Senate. My results are below. If you want to use a different set of assumptions, data is here:
https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1-eR-v77UuQCC95b15chNbNDxvclbpUzKzWHJYQTnSYw/edit?usp=sharing Number of failed nominations since 1945:
6 / 35 (Thornberry, Haynsworth, Carswell, Bork, Miers, Garland) Number of failed nominations since 1945 when same party controls White House & Senate:
2 / 20 (Thornberry, Miers) Number of failed nominations since 1987:
3 / 14 (Bork, Miers, Garland) Number of failed nominations since 1987 when same party controls White House & Senate:
1 / 9 (Miers) Conclusion? 
If the same party controls the White House and Senate, the nominee is approved except in the rare case -- 10% or so depending on denominator -- when the nominee is demonstrably unqualified and withdraws (Miers ) or the original occupant does not vacate which is not going to happen in this case (Thornberry).

For no confirmation to occur you would need for (a) Trump to not nominate anyone (he has already said he will do so quickly), (b) the Senate to refuse to vote (McConnell has already said they will vote), or (c) the Senate to deny a nominee. Initially, I believed that pressure on key Senators who are up for re-election had a small chance at stopping a confirmation. I now realize this is wrong for several reasons.
First, most of those seeking re-election have tied themselves to Trump in one way or another. It is also common knowledge that the GOPs base values SCOTUS appointees above almost any other issue. The only reason I've left 9% on the No is that they technically have until January 20th to push through any lame duck policies if they need to, so it may come through after the 1st. Updated my model [1] to reflect the open seat.  The main variable is time to replace before the question resolves. Since 1975, median days from nomination to vote is 72.5 with 23.8 days standard deviation. There are 124 days until this question resolves. Assuming that Republicans would fill the seat even if Trump loses the election, that gives plenty of time to fill the seat, a ~90% chance based on time alone. (Note: if you assume that Trump loses and Republicans would not fill it while he's a lame duck, that changes things dramatically, only 45 days until election, a ~13% chance of enough time to confirm. Also note that this is from nomination to vote and there's no one nominated yet and I imagine it would be at least a few days until someone is.) The second variable is that when a vote happens, whether it will be in favor of the nominee. Since 1954, 76% of nominees have been confirmed. Multiplying the above two variables (90% likelihood of enough time to fill seat * 76% chance of being confirmed) gives you a 69% chance of confirming a nomination by Jan 1. See explanations of the evolution of my model in my previous forecasts earlier this year. From the Economist 
“When Ruth Bader Ginsburg faced a fifth bout of cancer earlier this year, she repeated a pledge to keep serving “full steam” on America’s Supreme Court. Liberal Americans hoped she would live long enough to deny Donald Trump the chance to entrench a 6-3 conservative majority on the court. Following her death on September 18th, precedent would dictate choosing a successor only after the presidential election in November. But in the final strait of the campaign, politics is paramount. Mitch McConnell, the Republican majority leader of the Senate, promptly announced the vote would be held. With a long list of potential picks, there should be little delay in settling on a name. One favourite is Amy Coney Barrett, a judge on the Seventh Circuit Court of Appeals. A vote could take place before the November election. Mr Trump’s third Supreme Court appointee may yet be in a position to swing the outcome of the election if, as seems likely, the results in key states are contested in the courts.“

The average time it takes for a new justice to be voted in by the senate is 2.2 months (since 1975). However, the current COVID-19 crisis and the closeness to the Nov election may alter this time.  Trump may have less incentive to find a replacement because the current Justices have a political affiliation of 5 to 3 in his favor. However, he may want to speed up the process and get his nomination before the election, taking the decision away from the influence of a new democratic president.  If no Justice is confirmed before the election, one of the first things on the todo list of the new president will be the selection of a new Justice. However, if Biden wins, big decisions will begin on Jan 20 after his inauguration. I think a replacement seems more likely than not before the election but will become increasingly less likely with time, especially of Biden wins.

Updating my analysis from 1 month ago [1].  On the whole, my assumptions still hold — except that I now account for Ruth Bader Ginsburg's cancer recurrence and a probable increase in the eagerness of Senate Republicans to fill a vacancy since Biden is leading in the polls.  I still think this key observation by Richard Wolf of USA TODAY still holds: "By Labor Day, it would be difficult to get through the normal confirmation process by Election Day. And if Trump fails to win reelection or Republicans lose their Senate majority, it would be hard to justify filling a vacancy in a lame-duck session." [2] In other words, if a vacancy were to occur prior to Labor Day (which is on Sept. 7 - so it's about 1 month away), I think it's safe to assume that a replacement Justice will be confirmed by the Senate before Jan. 1 nearly 100% of the time. It gets much more complicated after that. According to the Congressional Research Service, the average number of days from nomination to a final Senate vote is 69.6 days (~2.3 months) while the median is 69 days [2]. It took 65 days to confirm Neil Gorsuch, who was nominated by President Trump and confirmed by Mitch McConnell's GOP Senate majority [3] — this is likely indicative of the speed at which such a confirmation process would occur (setting aside the confirmation of Brett Kavanaugh, which was unique due to the sexual assault allegations leveled against him). However, this process might yet be rushed if a vacancy were to open up before the election, given McConnell's general eagerness to confirm conservative Justices. So perhaps there is a ~90% chance of filling a vacancy that occurs between Labor Day and Election Day (~2 months). However, there is maybe only a ~40% chance of filling it between Election Day on Nov. 3 and Jan 1 (there are only 59 days between Election Day and Jan 1!). So, a vacancy will be filled 100% of the time if it were to occur between now and Labor Day, 90% of the time between Labor Day and Election Day, and 40% of the time between Election Day and Jan 1. Combining this analysis (see below) with the probability of a Justice dying as per Social Security actuarial life tables [4], which is now 8-10% (let's say 10% because of RBG's cancer recurrence) due to passage of time (now 5 months instead of 12 months), we get a final result of 7% for bin 1, 3% for bin 2, and 90% for bin 3. Note that I do not factor in the added risk of any of the judges dying from COVID-19 since the Supreme Court is now meeting virtually [5], which I think substantially lowers infection risk. Days between now and Labor Day: 35 
Days between Labor Day and Election Day: 57 
Days between Election Day and Jan. 1: 59 
Total number of days from now until Jan. 1: 151 Probability of vacancy filled between now and Labor Day: 100% 
Probability of vacancy filled between Labor Day and Election Day: 90% 
Probability of vacancy filled between Election Day and Jan 1: 40% Overall probability of a vacancy being filled between now and Jan 1: [(1*35)+(.90*57)+(.40*59)]/[1*151] = 0.73 = 73%. 
73% of the 0.10 that is left (since we have given bin 3 a 10% chance) gives us ~7% for bin 1 and ~3% for bin 2. One final thing to note: it seems unlikely that Clarence Thomas will retire in the near future — "His former clerk Erik Jaffe says activists on the right may try to ease him out before November, to ensure his seat is filled by a young conservative. But, he says, Justice Thomas 'sure as hell is not thinking about retiring.'" [6]. [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1066634

On average, in the 229 year history of the Supreme Court, there have been 113 judges appointed, which means there is a turnover rate of approximately one judge every two years, so an appropriate historical anchor is around 50% probability each year, or around 20.8% in 5 months. For the 55 that have retired, the average age of retirement is 73.6 years. Of those on the court now, only two are older than this age (though they are in their 80s), RBG and Breyer. So I'd bump my prediction up around 5 points. With the health issues surrounding RBG, I'd give it another 5 points that a seat opens up, giving a 69% chance no seat becomes vacant before January 1st. Now, the average time between a nomination and confirmation in recent history is 67 days, or a little over 2 months, though in the current political climate it is possible the Senate will attempt to ram through a decision in less time given that McConnell has staked his career on the courts. Given that the Republicans will still be in control of the Senate on January 1st (regardless of the election) I'd give it 70/30 odds that a vacant seat is not filled by then.

Our base rate is 146 days. That’s the median time it took from the setting of the first public hearing by the Senate Judiciary Committee until confirmation. That equates to 4.86 months. [1] Let’s round that to 5 for simplicity. That means, if a justice were to die tomorrow and a replacement was immediately named, it would take until approximately December 11 to confirm a nominee. This rarely happens. Since 1975, it has taken the President an average of 20 days to announce a candidate to fill a Supreme Court vacancy which brings us neatly to December 31, 2020. [2] I think this safely eliminates the confirmation of a replacement before January 1, not to mention the dynamics of COVID-19  and an election year. Let us turn then to the question of whether a seat will be vacated in the first place. The obvious and by far the most likely justice to vacate their seat is Ruth Bader Ginsburg. At the age of 87, she remains in vigorous health and will not want to retire as long as Trump is president. This is especially so given her historic longevity. With Biden the front-runner in the presidential race, Ginsburg will do all she can to stay on until the outcome is decided in November. [3][4][5] It is therefore almost certain in my view a Supreme Court seat will not be vacated before 1 January, nor a replacement confirmed. Please comment any thoughts. These percentages were summed to give a baseline probability of someone dying between now and 1 Jan as 14.373%. Adjustments: Ruth Bader Ginsburg (the oldest SCJ) was treated for pancreatic cancer in 2019. She also had lung surgery in 2019 to treat another cancer. Without direct access to statistical information on survival rates post-successful treatment for women her age it is hard to add an accurate modifier, not least because the general population at her age is also likely to already have numerous co-morbidities. Nevertheless if we take a rough guess and suggest it increases her percentage likelihood of dying in the next year by half, that would take her percentage from 9.22% to 13.83%, which would in turn adjust the overall probability of someone dying to 17.06%. Yes & No Replacement = Will remain at 1% until 8-10 weeks out, then will steadily increase as a relative proportion of the Yes forcast (while the yes forecast continues to decline steadily overall).

Updating my analysis from 1 month ago [1]. On the whole, my assumptions still hold. In particular, I think this key observation by Richard Wolf of USA TODAY still holds: "By Labor Day, it would be difficult to get through the normal confirmation process by Election Day. And if Trump fails to win reelection or Republicans lose their Senate majority, it would be hard to justify filling a vacancy in a lame-duck session." [2] In other words, if a vacancy were to occur prior to Labor Day (which is on Sept. 7 - so it's about 2.5 months away), I think it's safe to assume that a replacement Justice will be confirmed by the Senate before Jan. 1 nearly 100% of the time. It gets much more complicated after that. According to the Congressional Research Service, the average number of days from nomination to a final Senate vote is 69.6 days (~2.3 months) while the median is 69 days [2]. It took 65 days to confirm Neil Gorsuch, who was nominated by President Trump and confirmed by Mitch McConnell's GOP Senate majority [3] — this is likely indicative of the speed at which such a confirmation process would occur (setting aside the confirmation of Brett Kavanaugh, which was unique due to the sexual assault allegations leveled against him). However, this process might yet be rushed if a vacancy were to open up before the election, given McConnell's general eagerness to confirm conservative Justices. So perhaps there is a ~80% chance of filling a vacancy that occurs between Labor Day and Election Day (~2 months). However, there is maybe only a ~20% chance of filling it between Election Day on Nov. 3 and Jan 1 (there are only 59 days between Election Day and Jan 1!). So, a vacancy will be filled 100% of the time if it were to occur between now and Labor Day, 80% of the time between Labor Day and Election Day, and 20% of the time between Election Day and Jan 1. Combining this analysis (see below) with the probability of a Justice dying as per Social Security actuarial life tables [4], which is now 10-13% (let's say 12%) due to passage of time (now 6 months instead of 12 months), we get a final result of *% for bin 1, *% for bin 2, and 88% for bin 3. Note that I do not factor in the added risk of any of the judges dying from COVID-19 since the Supreme Court is now meeting virtually [5], which I think substantially lowers infection risk. Days between now and Labor Day: 73
Days between Labor Day and Election Day: 57 
Days between Election Day and Jan. 1: 59 
Total number of days from now until Jan. 1: 189 Probability of vacancy filled between now and Labor Day: 100% 
Probability of vacancy filled between Labor Day and Election Day: 80% 
Probability of vacancy filled between Election Day and Jan 1: 20% Overall probability of a vacancy being filled between now and Jan 1: [(1*73)+(.80*57)+(.20*59)]/[1*189] = 0.69 = 69%. 
69% of the 0.12 that is left (since we have given bin 3 a 0.88 chance) gives us ~8% for bin 1 and ~4% for bin 2. One final thing to note: it seems unlikely that Clarence Thomas will retire in the near future — "His former clerk Erik Jaffe says activists on the right may try to ease him out before November, to ensure his seat is filled by a young conservative. But, he says, Justice Thomas 'sure as hell is not thinking about retiring.'" [6]. [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1040896
[2] https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2020/02/13/supreme-court-battle-2020-democrats-gop-fighting-2016/4713579002/
[3] https://www.fas.org/sgp/crs/misc/R44234.pdf
[4] https://www.ssa.gov/oact/STATS/table4c6.html
[5] https://www.cnbc.com/2020/04/16/coronavirus-supreme-court-virtual-oral-arguments.html
[6] https://www.economist.com/united-states/2020/06/27/will-clarence-thomas-stick-it-out-for-a-30th-year-on-the-court

Updating my analysis from 1 month ago [1]. Key changes in addition to updating for passage of time: I am now assigning an 80% chance (previously 75%) of filling a vacancy that comes up between Labor Day and Election Day, and a 20% chance (previously 0%) of filling a vacancy that comes up between Election Day and Jan 1. I am making these adjustments due to the increasingly partisan dynamics of the U.S. Senate and forecasts that Democrats have a higher chance of taking back the Senate (which will probably motivate the GOP to quickly confirm a conservative justice to fill any vacancy).  Overall, a lot of my assumptions still hold despite COVID-19. In particular, I think this key observation by Richard Wolf of USA TODAY still holds: "By Labor Day, it would be difficult to get through the normal confirmation process by Election Day. And if Trump fails to win reelection or Republicans lose their Senate majority, it would be hard to justify filling a vacancy in a lame-duck session." [2] In other words, if a vacancy were to occur prior to Labor Day (which is on Sept. 7 - so it's about 3.5 months away), I think it's safe to assume that a replacement Justice will be confirmed by the Senate before Jan. 1 nearly 100% of the time. It gets much more complicated after that. According to the Congressional Research Service, the the average number of days from nomination to a final Senate vote is 69.6 days (~2.3 months) while the median is 69 days [2]. It took 65 days to confirm Neil Gorsuch, who was nominated by President Trump and confirmed by Mitch McConnell's GOP Senate majority [3] - this is likely indicative of the speed at which such a confirmation process would occur (setting aside the confirmation of Brett Kavanaugh, which was unique due to the sexual assault allegations leveled against him). However, this process might yet be rushed if a vacancy were to open up before the election, given McConnell's general eagerness to confirm conservative Justices. So perhaps there is a ~80% chance of filling a vacancy that occurs between Labor Day and Election Day (~2 months). However, there is maybe only a ~20% chance of filling it between Election Day on Nov. 3 and Jan 1 (there are only 59 days between Election Day and Jan 1!). So, a vacancy will be filled 100% of the time if it were to occur between now and Labor Day, 80% of the time between Labor Day and Election Day, and 20% of the time between Election Day and Jan 1. Combining this analysis (see below) with the analysis of @smitch15 that shows that the probability of a Justice dying between Jan 1 2020 and Jan 1 2021 is somewhere between 20-25% — which is now 12-15% (let's say 15%) due to passage of time (now 7 months instead of 12 months) — we get a final result of 11% for bin 1, 4% for bin 2, and 85% for bin 3. Note that I do not factor in the added risk of any of the judges dying from COVID-19 since the Supreme Court is now meeting virtually [4], which I think substantially lowers infection risk. However, the process to replace requires a certain minimum of time to execute.  The seat would need to be vacated before October to confidently state that the replacement would be confirmed before Jan 1.
The Process
The President usually will consult with Senators before announcing a nomination. When the President nominates a candidate, the nomination is sent to the Senate Judiciary Committee for consideration. The Senate Judiciary Committee holds a hearing on the nominee. The Committee usually takes a month to collect and receive all necessary records, from the FBI and other sources, about the nominee and for the nominee to be prepared for the hearings. During the hearings, witnesses, both supporting and opposing the nomination, present their views. Senators question the nominee on his or her qualifications, judgment, and philosophy. The Judiciary Committee then votes on the nomination and sends its recommendation (that it be confirmed, that it be rejected, or with no recommendation) to the full Senate. The full Senate debates the nomination. The Senate rules used to allow unlimited debate (a practice known as filibustering) and to end the debate, it required the votes of 3/5 of the Senate or 60 senators (known as the cloture vote).  In April 2017, the Senate changed this rule and lowered the required votes to 51 to end debate on Supreme Court nominations (this is commonly known as "the nuclear option"). When the debate ends, the Senate votes on the nomination. A simple majority of the Senators present and voting is required for the judicial nominee to be confirmed. If there is a tie, the Vice President who also presides over the Senate casts the deciding vote.

Ok, doing a 180 on this. Updating model [1] with two assumption changes that drastically change the calculus here. For full write-up of initial model methodology, see my initial forecast [2]. Assumption change 1: Retirement increases linearly vs exponentially. My initial forecast assumed that as you get close to 90, your likelihood of retiring (voluntarily or involuntarily) hits close to 100%. But, I'm coming around to the idea that there might be some justices who are simply "lifers" (like, arguably, RGB) who will simply continue working until they are forcibly removed by health reasons/death. I'm coming around to this idea despite the evidence against the idea of partisanship playing a role in a justice's retirement decision, perhaps because we are in such a partisan time that the historical research here doesn't apply. [3] Assumption change 2: Retirements would happen before the end of the term. I originally forecasted as if a retirement could happen up to the close of this forecast, but looking at the data more, it seems like most justices who retire do so usually in the summer before the end of the term on September 30th. There are two ways a vacancy would occur - retirement or death. Let's start with retirement. With retirement we are mainly looking at Clarence Thomas, Ruth Bader Ginsburg, and Stephen Breyer. There were some retirement rumors for Clarence Thomas back in June 2019 that he dismissed. Those rumors strike me as implausible, especially since they haven't come to fruition 9 months later. As for Ruth Bader Ginsburg and Stephen Breyer, they are both liberal leaning judges. Given their political leanings, I don't think either of them would leave office while Trump is in office. I won't anticipate the others retiring given the average retirement age of the last 11 justices was 80. Overall, it seems like a retirement will almost certainly not happen. The base rate is 44.5% of all justices have died in office and 55.5% have retired from office and other reasons [1].  But the current political environment makes using these statistics an iffy preposition.

Lets look at each of the two scenario – died in office and retirement, in the current situation. Listed below are the age and death probabilities within 1 year for the current Supreme Court justices, according to the Social Security actuarial life table for males and females [2].
Roberts - 65 - 1.58%
Thomas - 71 - 2.53%
Ginsburg – 86 – 8.24%
Breyer – 81 – 6.39%
Alito – 69 – 2.12%
Sotomayor – 65 – 0.98%
Kagan – 59 – 0.64%
Gorsuch – 52 – 0.60%
Kavanaugh – 55 – 0.78% The probability of having at least one vacancy due to death is the sum of all their fatality rates (24%).   (Actually there are other terms involving conditional probabilities and product of the individual rates.  Since the fatality rates are small, their products are much smaller than the 24% and therefore they are not considered in this calculation.)   I scaled the 24% for a year to 20% for the remaining 10 months.   Now look at retirement from office.  The potential retirees are the two liberal justices over 80 years old: Ginsburg and Breyer.  Despite having several bouts of cancers, Ginsburg is healthy. She will not retire in a Republican administration.  I give Breyer a small (2%) chance of retiring by the end of this year.  All the others are too young to retire and they will not in this political environment.  This gives a 22% probability of having a vacancy, or 78% for no vacancy.   It takes time to confirm a Supreme Court justice vacancy.  The last two vacancies (Gorsuch and Kavanaugh) took 66 and 90 days.  Lets round this to 2 months.  If a vacancy occurs within 8 months of the 10 months left, it is likely to be confirmed, leading to 0.8*22% = 18% probability.  If the vacancy occurs after 8 months, it is unlikely to be confirmed, leading to 0.2*22%=4% probability. Since the forecast probabilities are time dependent, they will be adjusted over time. Updating model [1] one day later after a night's sleep provided a few inspired enhancements. For full write-up of model methodology, see my initial forecast [2]. The main change is that rather than a crude model of assuming 50% retirement in the 4 years after retirement age (74.3), and 100% in the 16 years afterwards, I've plotted the frequency of a justice retiring in a given year relative to all eligible years for justices who have departed the court since 1954. For example, of the 13 justices who have been on the court at the age of 79, three retired during that year, a rate of 23%. Of the 4 justices who have been on the court at the age of 85, two (50%) have retired. The 1 justice still on the court at the age of 90 retired that year (100%). When we create a scatterplot of the frequency relative to each age year (screenshot [3]), we can see an exponential increase in retirement frequency as age increases. The data is definitely noisy, with a very low fit (R2=.065), but the trend looks visually convincing enough and logically it makes sense that retirement likelihood exponentially increases such that by 91.5 years old, a justice is 100% likely to retire in the next year, whether voluntarily or involuntarily. The trendline suggests a higher likelihood of retirement in the upper age ranges than I initially projected. For example, now, the model gives RBG a 48% probability of retiring at her current age of 86, and a 54% chance starting when she turns 87 in March. This is contrary to my previous model estimate of 23%. As detailed in my initial projection [2], I do not account for strategic retirement playing a role in any justice's likelihood of retirement. We should definitely be cautious here of the low sample size that I believe is causing such a low fit to the exponential trendline. Another change I made was to enhance the likelihood of enough time to nominate and replace a justice. Previously, I made a simple linear projection between 50% at the average length of a nomination, 100% for two times the average, and 0% for 0 days for a nomination. I now instead calculate the median length of a nomination (72.5 days), with a standard deviation (23.8 days), to plot the point on a normal distribution relative to the number of days remaining until the forecast ends. This doesn't affect anything now, as there is plenty of time to nominate and replace a justice, but should be better calibrated as we get closer to the average days left. I assume that since Republicans control the Senate and the presidency, they could push through a nominee even after we have 2020 election results in November, even if a Democrat is elected. A third very minor change I made was to see whether the death rates as provided by the actuarial tables I used should be adjusted under an assumption that justices live longer than the average population statistics used for the actuarial tables. I found that when comparing the death ages of male justices who departed the court after 1954, they on average were living only 4% longer than the male data shown in the actuarial table. I applied that death rate "discount" to all justices, but it obviously did not make much of a difference. Analysis: The resulting changes dramatically swing the likelihood of a departure this year to 100% (I've set a max of 99% just to not be overly dramatic). Between a 23% chance that any one justice dies plus a 25% chance of retirement based on age for Breyer plus a 48% chance of RBG retiring based on age, that gets you to nearly 100% without even accounting for retirement possibilities by other justices, namely 7% from Thomas. Model [1] based on age-adjusted 1-year death rate, years to/from average retirement age, manual adjustments for known health issues and retirement speculation, time to replace, and likelihood of confirmation. Finally, all component projects are adjusted based on time until forecast closes. Steps:
1. Calculate probability of death in next year based on age as shown in actuarial life table [2]
2. Linearly adjust probability of death based on time until forecast closes.
3. Calculate proprietary probability of retirement by end of current president's term. Assumes 50% likelihood of retirement at average age of supreme court justice retirement (74.26 years old for retirees since 1954 [3], the beginning of modern retirement provisions [4].) Assumes 100% likelihood of retirement (within four years) 10 years after retirement. Assumes 0% likelihood of retirement (within four years) 10 years before retirement. Linearly adjust for time remaining until end of term.
4. Linearly adjust probability of retirement based on time until forecast closes.
5. Sum the probability of death with the probability of retirement by forecast close for each justice.
6. Add 5% probability of departing for minor known health issue, 25% for intermediate known health issue, and 50% for major known health issue, all linearly adjusted for time remaining until end of forecast.
7. Add 5% probability of departing for minor retirement speculation, 25% for intermediate retirement speculation, and 50% for major retirement speculation, all linearly adjusted for time remaining until end of forecast.
8. Sum each justice's probability total. This is the likelihood of any single justice departing by forecast close.
9. Subtract from 1 to get likelihood of no single justice departing ("No" answer)
10. To determine likelihood of replacement, first calculate time remaining to replace, assuming 50% likelihood for 69.6 days left, the average number of days from nomination to final Senate vote [5], adjusted linearly to 100% for twice that amount of time and 0% for 0 days left.
11. Second, calculate historical confirmation rate since 1954. [6]
12. Finally, adjust confirmation rate by time remaining in term if the President and Senate are held by opposing parties. Current Projections:                      Death | Retirement | Health Issue | Retirement Speculation | Total
John Roberts:                 1%       | 3%               | 0%                  | 0%                                      | 5%
Brett Kavanaugh:          1%       | 0%               | 0%                  | 0%                                      | 1%
Samuel A. Alito, Jr:         2%       | 6%               | 0%                  | 0%                                      | 8%
Stephen Breyer:             6%       | 18%            | 0%                  | 0%                                      | 24%
Ruth Bader Ginsburg:   8%       | 23%            | 0%                  | 0%                                      | 31%
Neil Gorsuch:                 1%       | 0%               | 0%                  | 0%                                      | 1%
Elena Kagan:                   1%       | 0%               | 0%                  | 0%                                      | 1%
Sonia Sotomayor:          1%       | 2%               | 0%                  | 0%                                      | 3%
Clarence Thomas:          2%       | 8%               | 0%                  | 0%                                      | 10%
Totals:                              23%     | 59%             | 0%                  | 0%                                      | 82% Total likelihood of departure from the court: 82%
Likelihood of no departure from the court: 18% To determine likelihood of confirmation by forecast end:
Likelihood of enough time to replace: 100% (as of this writing)
Likelihood of confirmation: 76% Multiply that by 82% and you get a 62% probability of "yes and confirmed replacement". The remaining 20% serves as the likelihood of a departure but no confirmation. Final Model Projections: 62%, 20%, 18%
Crowd: 24%, 22%, 54% Analysis:  My model is significantly more likely to think than the crowd that there will be a departure this year, at an 82% rate vs 38% rate. The discrepancy seems primarily due to significantly higher projections of retirement (59% total vs 23% for death), whether voluntary or involuntary. In particular, given their ages, the model thinks both Breyer and Ginsberg have about a 20% chance of retirement. I think that is about right if one assumes that they will not retire voluntarily, in the hopes of waiting it out until a Democratic president is elected. That said, there is conflicting research over a justice's decision to retire strategically. This paper [4], argues that the political situation, if it has any effect on a justice's decision to retire, has a particularly weak effect, noting as an example RBG's decision not to retire during the Obama presidency among its additional empirical analyses. Because of this, I've chosen not to adjust retirement probability based on political allegiances, especially since retirement could just as easily be due to health decline or similar involuntary circumstance. The NY Times has a good article [7] summarizing this and competing research. Potential improvements to model:
* Better quantify and account for the weak effect of partisan differences or similarities between the justice and president/Senate
* Provide more granular death probabilities not simply based on age rounded to nearest whole year
* Adjust (voluntary?) retirement dropoff significantly if today's date is passed June, when most justices declare their retirement, suggesting low likelihood of retirement until the following June
* Better analyze historical confirmation rate for differences in rates when the presidency and Senate are run by opposing parties (not applicable for this particular question)
* Better analyze the dropoff in likelihood in confirmation based on days remaining (i.e. identify standard deviation); make assumptions for what would happen if a presidential election has happened and the results of said election.
* Generally, replace linear adjustments with normal distribution adjustments or something similarly more robust. [1] https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ZN2wk0VBJpuMyQy0ZZqL-1qJw8m_biLuuz5yo9n9hTE/edit#gid=1235802410

Excellent analysis out today in USA Today that discusses what might happen in this scenario.
"If a vacancy were to occur this presidential election year – with the staying power of 86-year-old Associate Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, a four-time cancer survivor, a perpetual subject of speculation – Democrats and liberals will say it should remain open through the November election...But with the White House and Senate in Republican hands, McConnell has said the 2016 precedent does not apply. He has vowed to confirm as many federal judges as possible...The only complication for Republicans might be the calendar. By Labor Day, it would be difficult to get through the normal confirmation process by Election Day. And if Trump fails to win reelection or Republicans lose their Senate majority, it would be hard to justify filling a vacancy in a lame-duck session" [1]. In other words, if a vacancy were to occur prior to Labor Day (which is on Sept. 7 - so it's ~7 months away), I think it's safe to assume that a replacement Justice will be confirmed by the Senate before Jan. 1 nearly 100% of the time. It gets much more complicated after that. According to the Congressional Research Service, the the average number of days from nomination to a final Senate vote is 69.6 days (~2.3 months) while the median is 69 days [2]. It took 65 days to confirm Neil Gorsuch, who was nominated by President Trump and confirmed by Mitch McConnell's GOP Senate majority [2] - this is likely indicative of the speed at which such a confirmation process would occur (setting aside the confirmation of Brett Kavanaugh, which was unique due to the sexual assault allegations leveled against him). However, this process might yet be rushed if a vacancy were to open up before the election, given McConnell's general eagerness to confirm conservative Justices. So perhaps there is a ~75% chance of filling a vacancy that occurs between Labor Day and Election Day (~2 months). However, there is probably close to a ~0% chance of filling it between Election Day on Nov. 3 and Jan 1 (there are only 59 days between Election Day and Jan 1!). So, a vacancy will be filled 100% of the time if it were to occur between now and Labor Day, 75% of the time between Labor Day and Election Day, and 0% of the time between Election Day and Jan 1. Combining this analysis (see below) with the analysis of @smitch15 that shows that the probability of a Justice dying between now and Jan 1. is somewhere between 20-25% - I'll say 20% due to the passage of some time - we get a final result of .15 for bin 1, 0.05 for bin 2, and 0.80 for bin 3. Days between now and Labor Day: 207
Days between Labor Day and Election Day: 57
Days between Election Day and Jan. 1: 59
Total number of days from now until Jan. 1: 323 Probability of vacancy filled between now and Labor Day: 100%

First, I will focus on the No vs Yes aspect of the question, and then will think about the conditional probabilities.  There are 5 conservative justices and 4 liberal justices [1]. Given Trump or at least a Republican will be the president until January 2021, the only way a liberal justice's seat is vacated is by death. Using an actuarial life table [2] we can compute this for the liberal justices. RBG is 86, Breyer is 81, Sotomayor is 65, and Kagan is 59. The probability of at least one of them dying is .082 + .06 + .01 + .005 = 16%. We can compute the same probability for the conservative justices. Roberts is 64, Thomas is 71, Alito is 69, Gorusch is 52 and Kavanaugh is 54. The implied probability of at least one death then is: .025 + .02 + .015 + .006 + .007 = 7%. This gives about a 20-25%  chance of a chair being vacated because a judge dies. Given that RBG also has a history of cancer scares maybe that probability should be a little higher. In addition, death isn't necessary, they may vacate if they become sufficiently sick. Hence, I will give a 30% chance that a judge dies this year, which implies a 70% chance of No.  Another factor to consider is that conservative justices may retire. It is hard to speculate about this. Given that all of these justices are relatively young, I would say that is highly unlikely. The average age of retirement is 73 [3] and given the controversy sparked by the fight over whether scalia's seat could be replaced during the last term of a presidential candidate year, I think the judges will try to avoid retiring this year. They all place a high value on the view of the court as an independent, authoritative body and another fight regarding a justice's retirement would only hurt that. Given that all of the conservative justices are young enough that they very well will see another conservative president after Trump if he loses I don't think they will retire. Hence, I'll say this will not occur. Since I say there is a 30% chance of a justice dying, I'll say 70% chance of No. I have a much less well developed view of the conditional probability of what happens if a vacancy occurs. I think the most likely outcome is that conservatives rapidly fill it. I do not know to what extent democrats can stall the proceedings since they do not have a majority in the senate. Hence, I'll put most of my weight in the replacement will be confirmed.  If anyone has any more information about the proceedings surrounding replacing a justice, I would be happy to hear.  [1] https://www.axios.com/supreme-court-justices-ideology-52ed3cad-fcff-4467-a336-8bec2e6e36d4.html
[2] https://www.ssa.gov/oact/STATS/table4c6.html
[3] https://www.scotusblog.com/2018/05/empirical-scotus-retirement-plan-blues/

Outside view:
If you use the data on death rates by age and sex from https://www.ssa.gov/oact/STATS/table4c6.html, plug in age and sex of the current Supreme Court justices, and do some simple maths, you get a 22% probability that at least one of them will die in the next year.  Inside view:
If you double Ginsburg's risk from 8.25% to 16.5% due to her many health scares, the overall probability goes up to 29%. Double it again to 33% and the overall probability is 43%.
Given that these people are relatively privileged, they probably have a higher life expectancy than the general population so that would revise the probability downward. So depending on how much of an expert you think you are on RBG's health (I'm not one) the overall probability is perhaps in the 20-40% range. What about whether they get replaced? Mitch McConnell has said he would do that. But it takes time - see https://www.nytimes.com/live/supreme-court-justice-antonin-scalia-dies-at-79/how-long-does-the-nomination-process-take/. That gives a mean of 73 days and a max of 99, with most above the mean.
Let's keep it simple and say if someone dies in the first 9 months of the year they get replaced before year end, otherwise it runs over into next year. So the probability of losing a justice gets further split 75% replacement - 25% no replacement.
I've gone for a 30% chance of someone dying, which breaks down as:
23% vacancy with replacement
7% vacancy with no replacement
70% no vacancy
I may update if more info comes in about anyone's health, or reasons to step down other than dying which I haven't considered here.

The base rate for a new SCJ is one every 2 years from 1790, and 2.5 years from 1945. The last SCJ was confirmed 1 year 3 months ago. The average confirmation length from 1970 is 67 days, but Brett Kavanaugh's confirmation took 89. If a seat hasnt been vacated by October, then the top bucket will look unlikely to be filled.  The two most likely justices to vacate their seats either through retirement or death are Ruth Bader Ginsburg or Stephen Breyer. @cafebedouin has the combined chance of death at 27.8% for all the justices, which broadly fits with the 2.5 base rate for a new justice.  There is also a chance that a conservative judge will retire to allow Trump to nominate another SCJ.
